journal-meta.journal-title: Journal for the Study of the New Testament

title-group.article-title: Suffering in Vain: A Study of the Interpretation of ΠΑΣΧΩ in Galatians 3.4

abstract.p: Modern scholarship is divided on the interpretation of πάσχω in Gal. 3.4, and there has yet to be a deﬁnitive study on the subject attempting to rectify the disagreements. The clear consensus prior to the late seventeenth century was that πάσχω possessed negative connotations in this passage. This interpretation was briefly challenged by Justus Christoph Schomer (1648–1693), influencing the majority of German scholarship and creating a major polarity among scholars in the English-speaking world. After making this history of interpretation known, the present study tries to demonstrate that, lexically, thematically and contextually, the preferable interpretation regards πάσχω as a reference to suffering, in keeping with the longstanding interpretative tradition.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The interpretation of πάσχω in Gal. 3.4 has posed difﬁculties to students of Paul for some time. A quick glance at the modern English translations reveals two basic options: some render πάσχω as ‘suffer’ (KJV, NASB, NET, ESV, HCSB, KNT) and others as ‘experience’ (NIV, NLT, RSV, NRSV). The same division is also represented in the relevant commentaries. There is no comprehensive or deﬁnitive study on the meaning of πάσχω in Gal. 3.4, and most interpreters just follow the lead of others. As a way forward, this study will seek to demonstrate that the most convincing interpretation is to recognize πάσχω as a reference to the suffering of the Galatians. I will ﬁrst provide a brief survey of the history of interpretation and then address exegetical concerns.

sec.title: 2. History of Interpretation
sec.p: The earliest extant commentators on Galatians—such as Chrysostom, Jerome, Augustine, Ambrosiaster, Theodore of Mopsuestia and Marius Victorinus—unanimously interpreted πάσχω as a reference to suffering persecution.1 Patristic interpreters understood the basic idea of Paul’s question in Gal. 3.4—τοσαῦτα ἐπάθετε εἰκῇ;—to mean that submitting to the law would cause the Galatians to lose ‘the merit of their suffering’, as Ambrosiaster stated (Bray 2009: 15). The only dissenting view noted by commentators is found in Jerome’s commentary, where he mentioned the perspective of some who understood πάσχω as ‘the burden of observing the law’ itself (Cain 2010: 124). Although this view presumably did not correlate πάσχω with physical affliction or persecution, it still rendered πάσχω as a kind of suffering with negative connotations.

This same interpretation is found throughout the medieval era. Haimo of Auxerre and Bruno the Carthusian interpreted πάσχω as suffering persecution (Levy 2011: 96, 149), and Robert Grosseteste also understood πάσχω as a reference to suffering, although he was ambivalent about the source of this suffering and noted the possibility that ‘laboring in legal observances’ could be in view (Levy 2011: 223-24). For Thomas Aquinas, Gal. 3.4 is about enduring ‘evils’ (Larcher 1966: 72). A similar strand of interpretation continued into the Reformation era of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.2

The ﬁrst interpreter to dissent from this line of interpretation was most likely the German theologian Justus Christoph Schomer (1648–1693).3 His commentary on Galatians, published posthumously in the early eighteenth century, contains a brief paragraph on the interpretation of Gal. 3.4, where he offers three reasons why πάσχω should not be rendered as ‘suffer’ (1706: 11). The reasons are: ﬁrstly, Paul makes no mention of adversity here (neque Paulus in praecedentibus ullam mentionem fecit adversorum); secondly, the context is about the Holy Spirit (Sed & antecedentia & consequentia docent de felicitate illorum agi, quam ex ﬁde senserint nempe de virtutibus Spiritus S.); and thirdly, πάσχω should be understood in light of ancient Greek writings (quo occurit apud Plutarchum & alios Scriptores Graecos). He then concludes that the sense of Paul’s question in Gal. 3.4 is: ‘have you felt the signs of divine grace in vain?’ (Tantane signa gratiae divinae sensistis frustra?). John Eadie (1869: 223-24) wrote regarding this interpretation that Schomer was ‘the ﬁrst apparently to propose it’ and both H.A.W. Meyer (1870: 128) and F. Sieffert (1899: 169) listed Schomer at the head of the list of interpreters who did not regard πάσχω as referring to suffering. Schomer did not cite any other interpreter for his interpretation of Gal. 3.4, and so it is likely that he was the ﬁrst to suggest it.

After Schomer there was a surge of this interpretation in the eighteenth century among German scholars, such as Herz Homberg, Johann Christian Schöttgen, George David Kypke and others (cf. Usteri 1833: 93-94). The same holds true in the nineteenth century among German scholars, such as L. Usteri (1833: 93-94), C. Holsten (1880: 90-91), R. Lipsius (1893: 35), F. Sieffert (1899: 169), and others, including some non-German interpreters as well (e.g. Brown 1853: 112; Jowett 1894: 142). To be sure, this was not the only view in the nineteenth century,4 but the fact that there were so many German interpreters from this period who did not interpret πάσχω as a reference to suffering also points to the likelihood that Schomer’s early eighteenth-century commentary was the initial influence for this interpretation.

Into the twentieth and twenty-ﬁrst centuries the scholarly divide increased.5 One major trend, however, was that German scholars tended not to interpret Gal. 3.4 as referring to suffering,6 with a few notable exceptions, such as Theodor Zahn and Adolf Schlatter.7 This trend can also be seen in the German Bible translations.8 The primary arguments given against interpreting πάσχω as a reference to suffering in Gal. 3.4 resemble the original points made by Schomer.

Now that the history of interpretation has been surveyed, I will address exegetical issues related to the interpretation of Gal. 3.4. The most important issues addressed here will be lexical evidence, the broader thematic conception of suffering in the letter, and the contextual appropriateness of a reference to suffering in Gal. 3.4 within Gal. 3.1-5. Historical questions will be set aside as secondary issues to be resolved elsewhere, after the legitimacy of πάσχω as a reference to suffering is considered from the literary evidence.

sec.title: 3. Lexical, Contextual and Thematic Evidence
sec.p: Aside from Gal. 3.4, the 6 instances of πάσχω in the Pauline corpus refer to suffering, which corresponds with the other 35 instances in the rest of the NT.9 Galatians 3.4 would then be a very odd exception.10 In the post-NT era, all 52 occurrences of πάσχω in the Apostolic Fathers refer to suffering.11 Likewise, of the 19 occurrences in the lxx, each relates to suffering.12 The same can be said of the 28 occurrences in the Pseudepigrapha,13 with the possible exception of a use of πάσχω in the Letter of Aristeas 214 where it may have a more general sense.14 In the complete works of Josephus πάσχω occurs 318 times. Of these occurrences, 9 of them do refer to positive experiences, although in those instances πάσχω is modiﬁed by the word εὖ, meaning ‘good’.15 There are 13 additional uses of πάσχω by Josephus that connote something other than harm or misfortune.16 This coheres with the broader Hellenistic usage of the term, as W. Michaelis noted in his own study on πάσχω: ‘In particular, the abs. use is always sensu malo. Hence the word is used sensu bono only when there is an addition to this effect or, very rarely, the context makes it sufﬁciently plain’ (TDNT, s.v. ‘πάσχω’). Thus, the term usually has negative connotations, as Michaelis noted, and in keeping with this there are nearly 300 examples from Josephus of πάσχω that refer to suffering, punishment and other negative experiences. However, for Philo the 207 occurrences of πάσχω in his writings often denote passive experiences more generally.

Of course, words are deﬁned by their context.17 For many scholars, both the broader context of the whole letter and the immediate context of Gal. 3.1-5 eliminate the possibility of interpreting πάσχω as a reference to suffering. In regards to the broader context, the words of Richard Longenecker are representative:
[I]f context is given primary importance, then a meaning sensu bono would appear … likely. For in the wider context of the letter there is no suggestion that the Galatian Christians had ever actually suffered any form of external persecution (Longenecker 1990: 104).

Yet there is at least one additional reference that could suggest that the Galatians were experiencing persecution. After claiming that the Galatians are Isaac-children (4.28), Paul then states in 4.29 that, just as the children of the flesh persecuted the children of the Spirit in the past (ἐδίωκεν), the same is true in the present (οὕτωϛ καὶ νῦν). This reference to persecution is often considered to be nothing more than Paul’s interpretation of the agitators’ attempts to convince the Galatians to receive circumcision.18 Yet it is quite likely that physical persecution is in view, and that this includes the actions of the agitators.19 Paul uses διώκω elsewhere in Galatians to refer to his former attempts to ‘destroy’ (πορθέω) the early Christian assemblies (1.13, 23), and to his present experience of persecution (5.11). It is possible that the additional references to Paul’s sufferings in Galatians—his ἀσθένειαν τῆϛ σαρκόϛ (4.13), his ‘birth pains’ (4.19), and the στίγματα τοῦ ’Ιησοῦ that he bears on his body (6.17)—are related to his experience of persecution. So, then, the question is why physical persecution would not be in view in 4.29. Paul also writes that the so-called agitators’ attempts to persuade the Galatians to receive circumcision were motivated by a fear of persecution (διώκωνται, 6.12). Some suggest that Paul’s comments in 6.12 are merely polemical rhetoric (e.g., Matera 1992: 230), but Paul’s persuasiveness would be in jeopardy if he were misrepresenting the situation (rightly Hardin 2008: 96). If the agitators were attempting to avoid persecution, regardless of the source of the hostility, this would then explain why their behavior towards the Galatians is described as persecution in 4.29. There is likely more at stake for them personally if the Galatians do not receive circumcision. Paul appears to hint at their hostile actions in 4.17 by claiming that the agitators are ‘zealous’ (ζηλοῦσιν), which recalls Paul’s own zealous persecution (ζηλωτήϛ; 1.13-14. Cf. also Phil. 3.6). For the Galatians to receive circumcision is to succumb to the conflict. Thus, when the broader context of the letter is surveyed, there appears to be an emphasis on suffering and persecution, which strengthens the interpretation of Gal. 3.4 offered here.

As an objection from the immediate context of Gal. 3.1-5, many scholars surmise that a reference to suffering in a context regarding the reception of the Spirit is unnatural. Gordon Fee (1994: 387) states that if 3.4 is a question about suffering, then ‘the question sits in the middle of an appeal to their experience of the Spirit, past and present, as something of a rock, with no speciﬁc reference to the immediate context’. Yet to suggest that suffering does not ﬁt the immediate context is difﬁcult to justify. First of all, Gal. 3.1-5 opens with the indictment that the Galatians are foolish to embrace the teaching of the agitators because the Messiah was ‘publically portrayed’ as cruciﬁed (προεγράφη) before their eyes (κατ’ ὀφθαλμούϛ). Different ideas have been proposed for how to interpret this use of προγράφω, but it is not necessary to make a decision here. What is crucial for the present study is the centrality of the cruciﬁed Messiah for Paul’s gospel. It could be that Paul is referring to the vividness of his kerygma,20 or, as Basil Davis suggested, Paul may be speaking of how he himself portrays the cruciﬁed Messiah, especially in his sufferings.21 This interpretation makes sense of the visual element of Paul’s words (κατ’ ὀφθαλμούϛ), and coheres well with the references to Paul’s experience of suffering in Galatians broadly. In the immediate context, this would also provide an expansion of Paul’s previous statements in Gal. 2.20 that the cruciﬁed Messiah lives ‘in him’ (ἐν ἐμοί). If this interpretation is preferable, then a question in Gal. 3.4 about the suffering of the Galatians and the potential of it occurring in vain would show the importance of suffering for the Christian community as Paul understood it. Indeed, on a few occasions in Galatians, Paul speaks of Christian existence as a cruciform lifestyle (Gal. 5.24; 6.14), which is not purely theoretical but has practical expressions in the hardships of the present evil age (Gal. 1.1). Regardless of whether or not this speciﬁc interpretation is convincing, it is clear that Gal. 3.1 is about the cruciﬁed Messiah. This is the main Christological emphasis in Galatians. At the outset of the letter Paul refers to the resurrection of Jesus (Gal. 1.1) and Gal. 2.20 likely alludes to this event as well, but the main emphasis in Galatians is on the cruciﬁed nature of the Messiah (cf. 1.4; 2.19-21; 3.1, 13; 5.11; 6.12, 14, 17). Rhetorically, then, one wonders why Paul chose to emphasize the Messiah’s and his own suffering in Galatians if this was not intended to have some bearing on how the Galatians were responding to their own suffering (Gal. 3.4; 4.29). Perhaps this is also connected to Paul’s request that the Galatians become like him (Γίνεσθε ὡϛ ἐγώ; 4.12)22 and—in light of the cruciform-Christological emphasis—that the Messiah becomes formed in them (μορφωθῇ Χριστὸϛ ἐν ὑμῖν, 4.19). Thus, it is not out of context for Gal. 3.4 to refer to suffering in the light of 3.1 and the reference to the cruciﬁed Messiah.

As a second counter-argument to the suggestion that a reference to suffering in Gal. 3.4 would be out of context because of the focus on the Spirit, it should be noted that Paul appears to be pointing to an underlying theology that associates suffering and pneumatology.23 In Gal. 4.29 it is the children of the Spirit who experience persecution, and it is possible—as Keesmaat has suggested (1999: 179, 181)—that the αββα cry in Gal. 4.6 is a cry in the midst of suffering, as it was for Jesus in the Garden of Gethsemane (Mk 14.36; Heb. 5.7-10). This would then parallel Rom. 8, where there are even stronger connections between the pneumatological αββα cry and suffering (Rom. 8.14-25). In the broader theology of Paul, we see similar associations of suffering and pneumatology, as in 2 Corinthians (see Hafemann 1986). Thus, rather than being antithetical to each other, Christian suffering takes place in the life of the Spirit.24

sec.title: 4. Conclusion
sec.p: In this study I have tried to demonstrate that the most convincing interpretation of πάσχω in Gal. 3.4 is that it refers to the suffering of the Galatians in correspondence with the unanimous interpretation before Schomer. This reading is not only compatible with the history of interpretation, it likewise coheres with the lexical evidence, the broader thematic emphasis on suffering and persecution in Galatians, and the immediate contextual evidence regarding both the centrality of the cruciﬁed Christ in Paul’s kerygma as well as the speciﬁcally pneumatological link with suffering. It is hoped that the present study will contribute to future research regarding the precise nature of the conflict in Galatia. Compounded by other important historical questions, such as whether Paul was writing to the inhabitants of North Galatia or South Galatia, and whether or not the Roman imperial cult contributed to the crisis,25 it was necessary to leave most historical questions aside for another study. It is believed that the present study can be incorporated into various reconstructions and so, regardless of which one is adopted, suffering appears to be integral to the situation.

fn.p: This is true for Chrysostom (Alexander, Broadus and Schaff 1894: 25), Augustine (Plumer 2006: 155), Marius Victorinus (Cooper 2006: 287-88), Ambrosiaster (Bray 2009: 15), Jerome (Cain 2010: 124) and Theodore of Mopsuestia (Greer 2010: 58-59). Cf. Meiser 2007: 125.
Cf. Luther [1535] 1979: 121; Calvin [1548] 2005: 48; Perkins 1617: 147; Fergusson 1659: 109-10. See also Locke’s paraphrase of Galatians in Wainwright (1987: 135).

Schomer’s commentary is not mentioned in any of the modern commentaries and is in large measure inaccessible. Only a handful of libraries in the world actually have a copy of the commentary, and so I am grateful to Paula Skreslet, Reference Librarian and Archivist at Union Presbyterian Seminary in Richmond, VA, for scanning portions of the commentary for me.
Some still interpreted πάσχω as ‘suffer’; so, e.g., Beet 1885: 75; Findlay 1891: 177-78; Lightfoot 1870: 249; Eadie 1869: 223-24.

For those twentieth-century interpreters who regard πάσχω as a positive reference, and not as a reference to suffering, see, e.g., Burton [1921] 1980: 149-50; Lagrange 1942: 60-61; Ridderbos 1953: 115 n. 5; Bonnard 1953: 63-64; Péry 1959: 37; Viard 1964: 63; Cole 1965: 90-91; Lyonnet 1966: 30; Bligh 1970: 232; Boice 1976: 454; Betz 1979: 134; Lull 1980: 78 n. 35; Krentz 1985: 45; Fung 1988: 133; Longenecker 1990: 104; Matera 1992: 113; Dunn [1993] 2001: 156; Fee 1994: 387; Martyn 1997: 285; Williams 1997: 85; Witherington 1998: 215; Cousar 2001: 56; Tolmie 2005: 107; Garlington 2007: 184; Harmon 2010: 132-33; Kelhoffer 2010: 36 n. 17; de Boer 2011: 180; deSilva 2011: 156-57.

For those twentieth-century interpreters who interpret πάσχω as ‘suffer’, see, e.g., Duncan 1934: 81-82; Guthrie 1969: 97; Bruce 1982: 150; Baasland 1984: 140; Goddard and Cummins 1993: 119; George 1994: 213; McKnight 1995: 141; Jervis 1999: 81; Cummins 2001: 102-103; Perkins 2001: 64; Nanos 2002: 189-91; Gorman 2004: 191-92, 206; Eastman 2007: 110; Wilson 2007: 85; Lopez 2008: 151; Schreiner 2010: 185.

Cf., e.g., Lietzmann 1923: 17; Schlier 1951: 83-84; Oepke 1964: 68; Schneider 1969: 56; Mußner 1974: 49; Lührmann 1978: 49; Becker 1981: 33; Ebeling 1981: 210; Borse 1984: 124; Egger 1985: 23; Radl 1985: 48; Krimmer 1989: 80; Vouga 1998: 69.

Zahn 1922: 145-46; Schlatter 1949: 71. Cf. also Michaelis who notes that πάσχω is ‘not used in a good sense’ in Gal. 3.4, but refers to ‘violent and beneﬁcial experiences’. This is a bit ambiguous, though he clariﬁes in n. 57 that the suffering was not the result of persecution. See TDNT, s.v. ‘πάσχω’.

For modern German translations that do not render πάσχω as a reference to suffering, see ‘erfahren’ in ELB, HFA, EU, NLB, NeÜ, and ‘erlebt’ in NGÜ, GNB. A notable exception is ‘erlitten’ in SLT. Most tellingly, the revised 1984 version of Luther’s translation contains ‘erfahren’ instead of the original ‘erlitten’.

In the early twentieth century, Preuschen’s Handwörterbuch listed two senses for πάσχω in the NT: all occurrences were designated under ‘schlimmen Sinn’ except for Gal. 3.4, which was listed as the only entry under ‘guten Sinn’ (1910: 882). So also BDAG, 785, which states that πάσχω occurs ‘only once in the sense experience someth. (pleasant)’ in the NT, referring to Gal. 3.4.
Letter of Aristeas 214 begins with πάσχομεν γὰρ κατὰ τὴν ψυχὴν ἐπὶ τοῖϛ ὑποπίπτουσιν ὡϛ θεωρουμένουϛ.

Cf. Josephus, Ant. 8.111 (εὖ πεπόνθασιν); 10.166 (εὖ πεπονθότοϛ); 12.134 (εὖ πάθοι); 13.147 (εὖ πάθοι); 14.295 (εὖ παθόντα); 15.18 (εὖ πάθοι); 16.140 (ἐπεπόνθεισαν εὐεργεσίαϛ); 20.154 (εὖ πεπονθότεϛ); War 1.426 (εὖ παθόντων).

For general uses of πάσχω, see Josephus, Ant. 3.312; 6.222; Apion 2.13. For the use of πάσχω to convey strong yet pleasant emotion, see Josephus, Ant. 2.184; 7.164; 15.52, 97, 218. For uses of πάσχω to convey anger, see Josephus, Ant. 3.22; 15.280; 16.45; 20.22. For passions generally, cf. Apion 2.251.
For etymological details, see Beekes 2009: 1156.

See, e.g., Burton [1921] 1980: 266; Fee 1994: 415; Witherington 1998: 337-38. It is often suggested that since the conflict between Isaac and Ishmael in Gen. 21.9 refers to Ishmael ‘laughing’ or ‘playing’ (mt: קחצ / lxx: παίζω), Paul does not have physical persecution in view in Gal. 4.29. Yet it is also noted by commentators that later rabbinic texts regarded Ishmael’s actions as physical persecution. Pirke de Rabbi Eliezer 30 and Pesikta Rabbati 48.2 describe Ishmael as an aggressive archer who attacked Isaac. Hostile interpretations can also be found in Josephus, Ant. 1.215, as well as in Gen. R. 53.11 and t. Sota 6.6, although the Midrash and the Tosefta also note other non-hostile interpretations as reflected in Jub. 17.4 and the Targums (Tg. Neoﬁti 21.9; Tg. Ps. Jon. 21.9; 22.1). It is beyond the scope of this article to address this matter further here, although I intend to do so in due course. Sufﬁce it to say, I think the key to the allegory of Gal. 4.21-31 is recognizing the Isaianic lens through which Paul interprets the Genesis narrative. By citing Isa. 54.1 in Gal. 4.27, Paul utilizes a passage about the end of exile that comes to fruition after the exilic suffering of Isa. 53. It is likely that this Isaianic influence colors Paul’s interpretation of Isaac and Ishmael’s relationship rather than rabbinic influence, which is both far too late and far too diverse.

Contra Cosgrove (1988: 83-84), who argues that διώκω never refers to inner-church conflict. Yet this begs the question of whether Paul would have conceived of the agitators as ‘insiders’ given his two-fold pronouncement of anathema on them (1.8-9), his pointed use of Gen. 21.10 in Gal. 4.30 regarding the fate of ‘the slave girl and her child’ as ‘cast out’, and his declaration that they ‘bear the judgment’ (5.10).

Betz wrote, ‘One of the goals of the ancient orator was to deliver his speech so vividly and impressively that his listeners imagined the matter to have happened right before their eyes’ (1979: 131). So most commentators; see, e.g., Burton [1921] 1980: 143-45; Lietzmann 1923: 17; Schlier 1951: 79-80; Bruce 1982: 148; Longenecker 1990: 100-101; Matera 1992: 112; Dunn [1993] 2001: 152; Martyn 1997: 283; Vouga 1998: 67; Schreiner 2010: 181-82; de Boer 2011: 171. Cf. TDNT, s.v. ‘progra&fw’.
Davis 1999: 194-212. Cf. also Hafemann 2000: 174; Gorman 2004: 188; Eastman 2007: 66.
So Goddard and Cummins 1993: 96-100.
Contra Cosgrove (1988: 187), who states, ‘the theme of suffering and the Spirit never becomes an object of reflection in Galatians’.

It may even be the case that Gal. 3.5 already points in this direction through the Spirit ‘working powerfully’ among the Galatians (ἐνεργῶν δυνάμειϛ; Gal. 3.5). When δύναμιϛ and cognates are used to refer to charismatic activity, it is always miracles that are in view (cf. Acts 8.13; 19.11; 1 Cor. 12.10, 28-29). This ‘powerful working’ may refer to the Spirit’s empowerment in the midst of suffering (1 Thess. 1.5-6; Rom. 8.26), and may even refer to miraculous healing within the community. Thus, if Gal. 3.4 is legitimately referring to an experience of suffering, it is not a non sequitur for Paul to transition into the miraculous work of the Spirit in 3.5.
See Kahl 2010; Hardin 2008; Nanos 2002.
